#Autism info point:

-Last minute spur of the moment plans often don't work for autistic children
-This can cause major distress as the child tries to cope with unexpected change
-Plan ahead & give the child time to process what will happen & reduce uncertainty

#Neurodiversity

text:
@Jsimlady @TheSims The problem isn't the trait. It's calling it neurodiversity in the article.

"Neurodiversity" was coined in 1998 by Judy Singer, to describe people with ASD, ADHD, Dyslexia, etc - people who's brain structures/wiring is different than the gen pop. from birth.

text: Neurodiversity affirmative therapists CAN be neurotypical - the therapist I had for 2 years was NT and was awesome, but we also acknowledge that shared lived experience may be significant for therapeutic alliances. It‚Äôs ok to ask about professionals‚Äô lived experience of ND.

text: The main principle of #neurodiversity affirmative #counselling and therapy is that we do not seek to correct or change a person‚Äôs inherent neurodivergent traits. We don‚Äôt see neurodivergence as deviance, defectiveness or pathology.

Social cues are confusing and based on past experiences your body may have learned that it can't trust what it believes. Your body will notice any natural changes in tone, facial expressions, and movement if your body is hyper focused on them.

text: @samhfarrell @epballou Neurodiversity covers everyone, including people with typical brain structures. text:

text:
'Diversity is being invited to the party, inclusion is being asked to dance'

A common quotation in policing, which assumes:
- Everyone enjoys parties
- Everyone can dance
- Everyone likes being the centre of attention

Can anyone think of a better one?
#Neurodiversity

text:
@wired_we @Thesismis @hughriminton @PeterWMurphy1 @EmRusciano Hang on, you clearly didn't listen very well.

text: @nouveau_moon @meganmadera @Nolutha54564940 @thisha_omuhle It's also really common to have more than one type of neurodiversity too, so dyslexia and ADHD is very common, but also autism, dyspraxia and dyscalculia. It's often hard to put individuals in neat boxes and the diagnosis can depend on which professional you see first.

text: @nouveau_moon @meganmadera @Nolutha54564940 @thisha_omuhle There is crossover between ADHD and dyslexia, as well as other types of neurodiversity.  You can have issues with executive functioning with both (planning, organisation, working memory etc). But dyslexia is primarily issues with phonics, ADHD primarily attention difficulties.
